(1 comment)

What if there's a mismatch between the IANA Id and the ASCII Model 'Compatible' name? Let's say i configure the IANA for Tyan but the 'Compatible' string says

"com.meta.Hardware.CPLD.LCMX02_2000HC".

Will the respective Code Update daemon be responsible to validate this or
entity-manager during config validation?

Is there a mapping from the 'ASCII Model' to the IANA Enterprise Ids?
Or how else would they validate the configuration.

Sorry for the basic questions.

> Will the respective Code Update daemon be responsible to validate this or
entity-manager during config validation?

The EM Configuration objects exposed via DBus will be consumed by CodeUpdater daemons. What goes into EM JSON config i have mentioned in next section which would be part of platform/board configs.

The CodeUpdater daemon will be responsible for validating this info against the descriptors in the PLDM image package (it receives for update). 

> Is there a mapping from the 'ASCII Model' to the IANA Enterprise Ids?
Or how else would they validate the configuration.

Any reason we need this mapping? EM exposes both of these and they both would be available for CodeUpdater to use.

> Any reason we need this mapping? EM exposes both of these and they both would be available for CodeUpdater to use.

Was just thinking about the potential for a mismatch between these 2 or the need to enter both when one could be derived from the other. 

But if 'Compatible' is used here the same as in devicetree, the 'compatible' vendor of the device does not have to be the same as specified via VendorIANA.

So i guess the mapping cannot be done in all cases, we can close this comment.

Can we rename 'VendorId' to 'VendorIdIANA'  or 'VendorIANA' or something like that to make it clear that it's an IANA Id and not something else.

So people do not have to look that up in some schema and it's obvious from the configuration.
Done
Should we go ahead and put Meta's IANA here for a complete example?
Done
I would suggest something more specific: `...Hardware.Yosemite4.MedusaBoard.CPLD.LCMX02_2000HC` ?
What if different boards have same kind of CPLD that uses same fw image? I am not sure if thats possible though? We would need different images just for different compatible parameter.

We need at least these components in the compatible:

Vendor
Hardware model
Chip model
Chip purpose


"CPLD" isn't actually necessary but is helpful for illustration purposes. 

Second-source would be handled by different chip model. 
2 CPLD with different purpose would be covered by the purpose.
Done
Have some comments/questions to understand the PLDM/Non-PLDM flow.
Done

How PLDM packages are to be handled is not very clear to me. I think there's some information in the "Multi part Images" section, but that doesn't answer all of the following questions I have:

1) It seems like the design expects a RedfishTargetURI must be provided by the user. However, that is not mandatory and would likely not be provided when the FW package is PLDM based. How does Bmcweb connect to the PLDM service in this case. Since PLDM can determine existing SW versions based on the Type 5 spec, it could create multiple SW versions based on how many PLDM FW endpoints are found.
- Is it the case that when no Target URI is provided, bmcweb will invoke StartUpdate on all services that implement this inteface and it is up to the service to determine whether the package is relevant or not (that sounds risky)?

2) How about the case where the the PLDM FW package has component images for PLDM and non-PLDM devices (we do this at Nvidia and I believe are not the only ones doing this) - which service is supposed to parse out the PLDM and non-PLDM components (pldmd/bmcweb)? It seems like the EM confgs below help in this regard, but not sure how.

> How PLDM packages are to be handled is not very clear to me. I think there's some information in the "Multi part Images" section, but that doesn't answer all of the following questions I have:
> 
> 1) It seems like the design expects a RedfishTargetURI must be provided by the user. However, that is not mandatory and would likely not be provided when the FW package is PLDM based. How does Bmcweb connect to the PLDM service in this case. '

The TargetURI needs to be supplied even for devices to be updated by PLDMd service.

> Since PLDM can determine existing SW versions based on the Type 5 spec, it could create multiple SW versions based on how many PLDM FW endpoints are found.

I suppose you are referring to the downstream devices discovered by PLDMd. If yes, then yes, the SW versions for downstream devices will be created by PLDMd based on discovered devices.

> - Is it the case that when no Target URI is provided, bmcweb will invoke StartUpdate on all services that implement this inteface and it is up to the service to determine whether the package is relevant or not (that sounds risky)?
> 
> 2) How about the case where the the PLDM FW package has component images for PLDM and non-PLDM devices (we do this at Nvidia and I believe are not the only ones doing this) - which service is supposed to parse out the PLDM and non-PLDM components (pldmd/bmcweb)? It seems like the EM confgs below help in this regard, but not sure how.

The FW package will be parsed by the CodeUpdater daemon and not BMCWeb. Depending upon the TargetURI, BMCWeb will send the Update request to the appropriate backend CodeUpdater daemon.

1) I think we need a design that works without target URIs as well. We can propose that as a follow up - Tom Joseph/I will propose that.

2) Consider a case where the FW package has 5 images - 3 PLDM and 2 non-PLDM. So in this case there would be three code updaters (1 PLDM and 2 for the non-PLDM). If my understanding correct so far? If so:

a) Will the Redfish user have to supply 5 Target URIs?

b) Since three target URIs correspond to PLDM devices, will bmcweb make 3 start update D-Bus calls to PLDMD? If not, how will it consolidate and know to make only one call to PLDMD?

c) Will Bmcweb use (yet to be added?) libpldm APIs for the FW update package parsing and splitting up into component image sections?

Also, 3) If Bmcweb is not parsing the package and the package has several PLDM + Non-PLDM images, will Bmcweb send the whole package to all code updaters? In that case the EM config becomes pointless. I think some amount of package parsing must be performed by bmcweb (using libpldm maybe).

This has been discussed via discord https://discord.com/channels/775381525260664832/778790638563885086/1303434176023892089, so marking this resolved. Please post any further general question related to design on discord as this PR is specifically for using PLDM image packaging for non-PLDM devices.
How are the supposed to be used? Can you give an example for PLDM package containing both PLDM and non-PLDM component images?

> How are the supposed to be used? Can you give an example for PLDM package containing both PLDM and non-PLDM component images?

PLDMd handles update for all PLDM devices. Since, PLDM image packaging is a standard and it is being used for other(non-PLDM) devices as well. Client needs to provide the appropriate TargetURIs to all Targets to which the image applies and BMCWeb will forward the request to appropriate backend CodeUpdater daemon (PLDMd and other non-PLDMd backends).
Discussed via discord https://discord.com/channels/775381525260664832/778790638563885086/1303434176023892089, so marking this resolved.
configurations or component images?
Configurations, for example, CodeUpdater for CPLD will handle firmware EM configurations related to CPLDs.
Done
What is the reason to do this mapping? Why did we pick only two descriptors from PLDM Type 5?

> What is the reason to do this mapping? Why did we pick only two descriptors from PLDM Type 5?

For non-PLDM devices these 2 fields seems to be sufficient to perform the image validation, as CodeUpdater daemon for non-PLDMd will use these values for image validation.
For PLDMd these values (from EM configuration) are not applicable as they would be fetched from downstream PLDM devices and used by PLDMd for image validation.
We can add more params as need be. We use UUID at Nvidia for the non-PLDM components.
Yes, you can use more standard descriptors as you see fit. I have updated description mentioning that this is bare minimum required.

@Deepak, I suppose you are referring to "0x0002 – UUID" in PLDM FW spec? If yes, then how is the UUID used in case of non-PLDM components? In mean since there is no downstream device to query from where do you get UUID for non-PLDM device to match the FW image?

> I suppose you are referring to "0x0002 – UUID" in PLDM FW spec?

Yes

> In mean since there is no downstream device to query from where do you get UUID 
> for non-PLDM device to match the FW image?

The devices that can be updated in a non-PLDM could be programmed with UUID at the time of manufacturing. Another example, if I classify the OCP recovery as non-PLDM updater, DEVICE_ID supports a bunch of Initial Descriptor Type (PCI, IANA, UUID etc)
https://www.opencompute.org/documents/ocp-recovery-document-1p0-final-1-pdf

Thanks for the information.

As mentioned above, you can add more parameters to EM configuration as per your need. I am marking this as resolved, let me know if there are any other questions.
Thanks for responding. I still have a couple followup questions.
Done
Any reason not starting to use the latest specification? 1.3.0

No specific reason. The descriptors of interest for updaters (for non-PLDM devices) are already included in the initial specification, so it doesn't matter. However, I have updated the link to the latest version and also updated the wording to better reflect it.
Why only IANA and ASCII Model is mentioned here, I think the BMC code should be descriptor agnostic (can handle all descriptor types)

These two descriptors provided the minimum information necessary for a non-PLDM device to validate whether an image was intended for it or not. I have updated the description to make it more explicit. If anyone needs to use more standard descriptors in their CodeUpdaters, they can do so at any time.

according to PLDM spec, IANA number is 4 bytes,
so we should encode it as a number, right?

like
```
"VendorIANA": 0x0000a015,
```
Done

`minimum` - The PLDM spec doesn't mandate descriptors, it could be PCIe descriptors, UUID of the device etc. IANA/ASCII model is a good example, will prefer the text to be flexible.

For example, if I classify the OCP recovery as non-PLDM updater, DEVICE_ID supports a bunch of Initial Descriptor Type (PCI, IANA, UUID etc)

https://www.opencompute.org/documents/ocp-recovery-document-1p0-final-1-pdf

Just to be clear the EM configuration, names the properties to be generic enough and uses standard terms such as VendorIANA. What i have defined below is what they can map to in PLDM spec. I have removed the word 'minimum' to avoid any confusion.
Say this chip was also handled by psusensor.  It would share the same stansa as the dbus-sensors config with all the threshold and everything then?

Ideally, it should be the case, but I anticipate diverse opinions on this matter. Therefore, I will leave it to the discussion on EM schema definition for specific components when that takes place. The scope of this PR is limited to defining a common firmware parameters (VendorIANA, Compatible) & schema that can be utilized across various fw definitions.

Please let me know if you have any questions or concerns?
Updated this example as per latest schema definition in EM. Let me know if you have any questions here. Marking this as resolved for now.

If, for example, the CPLD can only be updated when power is off but someone tries to do it with power on, does the CPLD specific updater code just know that and deal with it, or does a power state also need to be specified in here?

CPLD specific updater code will know about it. Also it can be handled as part of some pre update condition too, which is the next patch in the series (https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/docs/+/75500), in that patch its being discussed to see if specific target names can be moved to EM config or not? Whats your opinion?
On the platform I am working host needs to be powered ON for the CPLD update to happen, will review the follow up MR.
Marking this as resolved as this comment is not related to the PR in question but the subsequent PR in stack. Please provide any relevant comments there.
LGTM, couple of minor comments.

I think we can enhance this statement to better reflect the flexibility of CodeUpdaters. I suggest rephrasing it to emphasize that CodeUpdaters can work with a variety of PLDM descriptors, not just a fixed set.

`For such devices, the images can be packaged using PLDM package format by choosing PLDM descriptors applicable to the device. The CodeUpdater will parse the entity manager configuration to identify the PLDM descriptors applicable for it. Below is an example: ..."

define `Name` field as well, 

How will `Name` field be used by the CodeUpdater service?

`Able to update multiple hardware components of same type running different
 firmware images, for example, two instances of CPLDx residing on the board,
 one performing functionX and other performing functionY and hence running
 different firmware images.`

Is the `Name` used to identify what specific CPLD firmware is needed?
